head.title: kcgi | minimal CGI library for C

body.header:
kcgi — minimal CGI library for C
version @VERSION@ Sources Archives

article.p: kcgi is a minimal CGI library for web applications (HTML and HTTP) in ISC licensed ISO C. It was designed to be secure and auditable. See a Comparison of CGI Libraries in C for alternatives. To start, download kcgi.tgz and run make install into your PREFIX of choice. The kcgi(3) manpage documents usage. kcgi is a BSD.lv project.

div.p: Process separation of parse context. Now, khttp_parse forks a child process to parse input data, which returns well-defined results to the parent over a socketpair. Moreover, khttp_parse does not exit on failure, but instead returns an error to the caller. Audited all other kcgi internal functions so that they don't exit on failure, but return an error code to the caller. Finally, for consistency with OpenBSD, kxrealloc and krealloc have been renamed krealloc and kreallocarray, respectively.

article.p: The following is a rough feature list of kcgi. See the manual for details.

ul.li: input: query string, cookie, and form (multipart form-data and mixed, urlencoded, and plain)
lightweight functions for building HTML5 trees and HTTP headers
security: process-separation of input data parsing

article.p: Most kcgi applications work as follows (the sample.c file distributed in the source consists of a full working example):

ol.li: Call khttp_parse as early as possible. This will parse input and cookie fields and set up the HTTP environment. At present, kcgi parses (and optionally validates) cookies; query string GET data; and the urlencoded, form-data, and plain POST data. These use kvalid_double, kvalid_email, kvalid_int, kvalid_string, kvalid_udouble, kvalid_uint, or locally-defined functions for validation. It also maps page and MIME requests.

Process input fields by examining the struct kpair elements of the main struct kreq structure. This main structure contains all parsed input fields and environment information (in the interests of simplicity, kcgi uses a single structure instead of accessor functions).
Emit HTTP headers with khttp_head, followed by khttp_body to begin the HTTP body. The latter will automatically trigger compression, if requested by the client.
Emit HTTP body output using HTML5 tree-building functions khtml_attr, khtml_attrx, khtml_close, khtml_closeto, khtml_elem, khtml_elemat, khtml_entity, khtml_int, khtml_ncr, or khtml_text; or
use the khtml_template function to populate file templates with a mixture of HTML-building functions; or
use khttp_putc and khttp_puts for non-HTML media.
Call khttp_free to close the HTTP document and free all memory.

article.p: This library is still quite new. Contact Kristaps with questions or comments.

As a security precaution, the kcgi library parses untrusted network data in a child process. When invoked, khttp_parse will fork. The child process is responsible for reading and parsing form data from the web server. This parsed data is returned to the parent process over a socketpair.
Originally, the OpenBSD imsg approach was used, but this is constrained in message size due to the underlying SOCK_DGRAM usage. The socket communication in kcgi uses SOCK_STREAM.
If HAVE_ZLIB is enabled during compilation (via the Makefile), kcgi will use zlib to compress the HTTP body. Compression is only enabled if the correct (gzip) HTTP request header is provided.

All common input methods—query string, cookie, and form (multipart form-data and mixed, urlencoded, and plain—are supported by kcgi. As described in the Security section, these fields are all parsed from network data in a child process.
